meta.defaultDescription: Free, open-source security tools that run 100% in your browser. Encrypt text, hash files, test passwords, and hide messages in images — no data ever leaves your device.
offline.banner: You're offline — cached tools still work.
lang.label: Language
home.hero.subtitle: A comprehensive toolkit for digital self-defense. From classic mechanical ciphers to modern metadata scrubbing — everything runs 100% in your browser.
home.instruments.title: Precision
home.instruments.subtitle: Categorized tools designed for specific privacy needs. Pick your focus and secure your life.
home.dev.title: The Developer's Shield.
home.dev.text: Advanced tools for hashing, JWT debugging, and secure identifier generation. Everything a modern engineer needs for production-ready security.
home.crypto.title: Old School Cool.
home.crypto.text: Relive history with our Enigma M3 simulator. Explore Caesar, Vigenère, and the uncrackable ciphers of the past. Cryptographic history, interactive and visual.
home.privacy.title: Everyday Defense.
home.privacy.text: Scrub EXIF metadata from photos, watermark IDs for safe sharing, and generate tracker-free QR codes. Practical tools for protecting your personal images.
home.vault.title: Human-Readable.
home.vault.text: Our original tool. Encrypt any text into a list of memorable dictionary words. Military-grade AES-256-GCM encryption meets lexical mapping.
home.why.title: Why encrypt.click?
home.why.p1: Online tools are often traps. When you use a "free" password checker or encoder, your data is likely being logged on a server you don't control.
home.why.p2: Everything on this site runs exclusively in your browser memory. We have no backend database. We don't want your data.
home.why.p3Rest: . Verify it. Fork it. Run it locally.
home.trust.title: Built on
home.trust.subtitle: Zero Logs · Zero Trackers · Pure Math
home.cta.title: Start sharing
home.cta.subtitle: No accounts. No trackers. Just pure cryptographic peace of mind.
404.meta.title: 404 — Page Not Found
404.meta.description: The requested page could not be found in our secure registry.
404.text: The resource you are looking for has either been relocated, encrypted beyond reach, or never existed in this sector.
drop.meta.title: Dead Drop Link — Data in the URL
drop.meta.description: Encrypt text or small files directly into the URL fragment. Nothing ever touches a server.
drop.subtitle: Create one-shot links where the entire encrypted payload lives in the URL hash. No backend. No logs. Just math in your browser.
security.meta.title: Security & Privacy (Privacy Policy) — encrypt.click
security.meta.description: Privacy policy for encrypt.click: how client-side crypto works, what data is (and isn't) sent to servers, and how optional URL shortening works.
security.subtitle: Plain-language privacy policy describing how encrypt.click treats your data. This is informational only and not legal advice.
security.noAccounts.title: No accounts, no logins
security.noAccounts.text: encrypt.click does not have user accounts, logins, or profiles. You do not need to register or provide any personal information to use the tools.
security.clientSide.title: 100% client-side tools
security.clientSide.p1: All cryptographic operations are performed in your browser using the Web Crypto API and other local APIs. For the core tools, inputs (text, files, passwords, keys) are never sent to any backend controlled by encrypt.click.
security.clientSide.p2: For the Dead Drop tool specifically: the payload is compressed and encrypted locally and stored in the URL fragment (the part after #). URL fragments are not sent to encrypt.click servers during normal page requests.
security.clientSide.p3: Some tools may fetch public data or randomness from third-party APIs that you explicitly invoke (for example, the Drand randomness beacon for the Time Capsule). These calls never include your plaintext secrets or passwords.
security.shortening.title: Optional URL shortening
security.shortening.p1: If you choose to shorten a link (for example from the Dead Drop page), your browser calls /api/shorten on encrypt.click. The encrypt.click backend then makes a server-side request to the shortener you selected.
security.shortening.p2: The shortener will receive the full URL you are shortening. For Dead Drop links, that includes the URL fragment containing the encrypted payload. The payload is encrypted, but it can still be a unique identifier and may be considered sensitive metadata. If you want maximum privacy, do not use third-party shorteners for Dead Drop links.
security.shortening.p3: When you share a shortened link from encrypt.click, the URL you share is still on the encrypt.click domain. When someone clicks it, their browser talks to encrypt.click first. encrypt.click then contacts the shortener on their behalf and follows the redirect server-side before redirecting the visitor back to an encrypt.click URL. This design means the shortener sees requests from encrypt.click infrastructure, not directly from the visitor's IP address, although the shortener can still log that a given encrypted link was used.
security.cookies.title: Cookies and local storage
security.cookies.p1: The site does not set tracking or analytics cookies, and does not use third-party trackers or ad pixels. Your browser may use localStorage only to remember your preferred light/dark theme. This value does not contain personal data.
security.cookies.p2: Cloudflare (our hosting provider) may set cookies for security and abuse prevention depending on traffic patterns and your browser settings, under Cloudflare's own policies.
security.network.title: Network and transport security
security.network.li1: All traffic is served over HTTPS with modern TLS configuration.
security.network.li2: HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) is enabled with includeSubDomains; preload.
security.network.li3: Content Security Policy (CSP) restricts scripts, styles, fonts, and connections to trusted origins only.
security.network.li4: Framing is disabled via frame-ancestors 'none' and X-Frame-Options: DENY.
security.thirdParty.title: Third-party infrastructure
security.thirdParty.p1: encrypt.click is hosted on Cloudflare Pages. Cloudflare, as a reverse proxy and CDN, may log standard HTTP metadata (such as IP address and user agent) for security and operational purposes, according to their own privacy policy.
security.thirdParty.p2: The application itself does not maintain its own server-side logs of your tool inputs. For abuse prevention, encrypt.click applies rate limiting on API endpoints (such as the Drand proxy and URL shortener). Rate limiting uses a one-way hash of your IP address (salted SHA-256, truncated) stored only in memory for a short window (about 60 seconds) and is not written to a database by the application.
security.disclosure.title: Responsible disclosure
security.disclosure.text: If you believe you have found a security or privacy issue in encrypt.click, please contact security@encrypt.click. Include enough detail to reproduce the issue and avoid testing that could impact other users.
security.nonLegal.title: Non-legal summary
security.nonLegal.text: This page is a human-readable summary of how encrypt.click is designed to handle your data. It is not a contract and not a full legal terms-of-use document. By using the site, you accept that no guarantee of perfect security can be made and that you use the tools at your own risk.
tools.aesWords.meta.title: AES Words — Lexical Cryptography
tools.aesWords.meta.description: Convert your encrypted data into human-readable word sequences. High-security AES-256 encryption mapped to a 14-bit dictionary.
tools.aesWords.subtitle: Our proprietary format that turns encrypted payloads into easy-to-copy word buckets. AES-256-GCM core with salted key derivation.
tools.aesWords.info.title: How it works
tools.aesWords.info.text: 1. Your text is encrypted with AES-256 using your secret password. 2. The resulting binary data is split into 14-bit chunks. 3. Each chunk is mapped to one of 16,384 unique words in our dictionary.
tools.aesWords.errorBoth: Please enter both text and a password.
tools.aesWords.errorGeneric: An error occurred during processing. Check your password or input.
tools.base64.meta.title: Base64 Encoder & Decoder — Data Transformation
tools.base64.meta.description: Convert text to Base64 and vice versa instantly. Secure and local data transformation.
tools.base64.subtitle: Essential utility for data transmission and encoding.
tools.base64.info.title: Encoding vs. Encryption
tools.base64.info.text: Base64 is an encoding scheme, not encryption — it provides zero confidentiality. It converts binary data into printable ASCII characters so it can be safely transmitted through text-only channels like email, JSON, or URLs. Anyone can decode it instantly. Never use Base64 to protect sensitive data.
tools.bcrypt.meta.title: Bcrypt Hash Generator & Verifier — Password Security
tools.bcrypt.meta.description: Hash and verify passwords locally using the industry-standard Bcrypt algorithm. Totally private and secure.
tools.bcrypt.subtitle: Verify identity without storing cleartext. Local-first implementation.
tools.bcrypt.info.title: Security Standard
tools.bcrypt.info.text: Bcrypt is a robust hashing algorithm designed to be computationally expensive (slow) to prevent brute-force attacks. It includes a built-in salt to defend against rainbow table attacks.
tools.bcrypt.matchText: The provided text matches the hash.
tools.bcrypt.invalidText: The text does not correspond to this hash.
tools.bip39.meta.title: BIP39 Mnemonics Generator — Crypto Seed Phrases
tools.bip39.meta.description: Generate cryptographically secure 12-word recovery phrases for crypto wallets and encrypted containers following the BIP39 standard.
tools.bip39.subtitle: Securely derive human-readable entropy for wallet restoration and secret storage.
tools.bip39.info.title: Standard Compatibility
tools.bip39.info.text: The Bitcoin Improvement Proposal 39 (BIP39) describes the implementation of a mnemonic sentence — a group of easy-to-remember words — for the generation of deterministic wallets. This generator is compatible with Ledger, Trezor, and major software wallets.
tools.bip39.warning: Never share your mnemonic phrase. It grants full access to any associated wallet or encrypted container derived from these bits.
tools.caesar.meta.title: Caesar Cipher — Rotational Encryption
tools.caesar.meta.description: The legendary shift cipher utilized by Julius Caesar. Shift the alphabet to encrypt secrets and learn the fundamentals of cryptanalysis.
tools.caesar.subtitle: The foundation of cryptography. Rotating the alphabet by a fixed offset to hide your words.
tools.caesar.info.title: Historical Background
tools.caesar.info.text: Named after Julius Caesar, who used it to protect military correspondence around 50 BC. With only 25 possible shifts, it can be brute-forced in seconds — making it a perfect teaching tool for understanding substitution ciphers, but entirely unsuitable for real security. ROT13 (shift 13) is a well-known special case still used for spoiler text.
tools.enigma.meta.title: Enigma M3 Simulator — WWII Cryptanalysis
tools.enigma.meta.description: Experience the history of cryptography with a functional simulation of the Wehrmacht Enigma M3 machine. Configure rotors and scramble messages locally.
tools.enigma.subtitle: A precise digital reconstruction of the 1940s electro-mechanical rotor cipher machine.
tools.enigma.info.title: Technical Specs
tools.enigma.info.text: Configured as the Standard Army M3. Uses Rotor I, II, and III with Reflector B. Implements the "double stepping" rotor anomaly for historical accuracy.
tools.exifScrub.meta.title: EXIF Scrubber — Metadata Eraser
tools.exifScrub.meta.description: Strip hidden metadata from your photos. Remove GPS coordinates, camera specs, and timestamps before sharing online for maximum privacy.
tools.exifScrub.subtitle: Photos leak more than you think. Our tool redraws the image to a clean canvas, leaving zero trace of the original metadata.
tools.exifScrub.info.title: Privacy Log
tools.exifScrub.info.text: Standard EXIF strippers just delete headers. We take it a step further by redrawing the raw pixel data onto a new canvas, ensuring even proprietary manufacturer tags are completely destroyed.
tools.exifScrub.metadataRemoved: GPS, Camera Model, Timestamps will be removed
tools.exifScrub.imageTooLarge: Image too large. Please keep under 10 MB.
tools.exifScrub.newFileGenerated: New file generated without original metadata headers
tools.anonUpload.meta.title: Anonymous Upload — Privacy-Safe File Sharing
tools.anonUpload.meta.description: Anonymize files with randomized names and stripped EXIF, then upload directly from your browser. No backend proxy — maximum privacy.
tools.anonUpload.subtitle: Randomize filename, strip EXIF metadata, reset capture dates. Upload directly to temporary hosts — your file never touches our servers.
tools.anonUpload.anonSteps: Random name · EXIF stripped · Date reset to 1990
tools.anonUpload.uploadFailed: Upload failed. Try downloading and uploading manually to a Send instance.
tools.anonUpload.sendManual: Download the anonymized file above, then open a Send instance and drag the file in.
tools.anonUpload.info.title: Privacy-first design
tools.anonUpload.info.text: All anonymization runs in your browser. One-click upload goes directly to tmpfiles.org or 0x0.st — encrypt.click never receives your file. For Send instances (end-to-end encrypted, larger limits), download the anonymized file and upload manually. No backend proxy means no logs, no storage, no liability.
tools.hmac.meta.title: HMAC SHA-256 Signer — Message Authentication
tools.hmac.meta.description: Generate hash-based message authentication codes (HMAC) locally to verify message integrity and authenticity.
tools.hmac.subtitle: Verify data integrity and source authenticity with SHA-256 signatures.
tools.hmac.info.title: Integrity Assurance
tools.hmac.info.text: HMAC combines a cryptographic hash function with a secret cryptographic key. It is used to verify both the data integrity and the authenticity of a message.
tools.jwt.meta.title: JWT Debugger — Local Token Decoding
tools.jwt.meta.description: Decode and analyze JSON Web Tokens (JWT) locally. Inspect headers and payloads without exposing tokens to external servers.
tools.jwt.subtitle: Deep-dive into token headers and claims. Processed locally for zero-leak analysis.
tools.jwt.info.title: Claims Inspection
tools.jwt.info.text: Verify expiration times (exp), issued-at times (iat), and custom claims instantly. Note: This tool decodes the Base64 chunks but does not verify the signature against a secret.
tools.morse.meta.title: Morse Code Codec — Signal Translation
tools.morse.meta.description: Translate text to Morse code and vice versa. Play resulting signals via your browser's audio engine for a fully interactive experience.
tools.morse.subtitle: Convert between alphanumeric characters and the universal dot-dash telegraphy standard.
tools.morse.info.title: Universal Standard
tools.morse.info.text: Developed by Samuel Morse and Alfred Vail in the 1830s, Morse code encodes letters as sequences of dots and dashes. It remains an official communication method in aviation and maritime emergencies (SOS = ··· −−− ···). Unlike encryption, Morse code is a public encoding — anyone who knows the standard can read it.
tools.pdfRedact.meta.title: PDF Redactor — Block Sensitive Pixels
tools.pdfRedact.meta.description: Redact sensitive information from your PDF documents locally. Ensure private data is permanently obscured before sharing.
tools.pdfRedact.subtitle: Black out secrets. Permanently obscure text and images in your PDF files using local-first processing.
tools.pdfRedact.infoP1: All redaction happens locally in your browser. The PDF is rasterized page-by-page and rebuilt with black boxes burned into the pixels and metadata stripped.
tools.pdfRedact.infoP2: Upload a PDF, draw black rectangles over sensitive areas on each page, then download a new, fully rasterized copy.
tools.pdfRedact.processedInMemory: Processed in-memory · Max size {size} MB · Large PDFs may be slow.
tools.pdfRedact.drawInstructions: Click and drag to draw black boxes. Repeat on any page that needs redaction.
tools.pdfRedact.drawAtLeast: Draw at least one redaction box on a page.
tools.pdfRedact.pdfTooLarge: PDF too large. Please keep under 5 MB.
tools.pdfRedact.failedToProcess: Failed to process PDF. Try a smaller document or fewer pages, and make sure the file is a valid PDF.
tools.pdfRedact.info.title: Why Rasterize?
tools.pdfRedact.info.text: Simply placing a black rectangle over text in a PDF does not remove the underlying data — the text layer remains selectable and searchable. Our tool rasterizes each page into pixels and redraws the redaction boxes directly onto the bitmap, then rebuilds the PDF. This permanently destroys the original text data under the redacted areas.
tools.pdfUnlock.meta.title: PDF Unlocker — Remove Protection
tools.pdfUnlock.meta.description: Strip passwords and restrictions from your PDF files locally. Regain full access to your documents in seconds.
tools.pdfUnlock.subtitle: If you have the key, we can unlock the door permanently. Saves an unencrypted copy of your protected PDF.
tools.pdfUnlock.failedToUnlock: Failed to unlock PDF. Password might be incorrect or file is not encrypted.
tools.pdfUnlock.docUnlocked: Document is now unlocked and ready for download
tools.pdfUnlock.pdfTooLarge: PDF too large. Please keep under 5 MB.
tools.pdfUnlock.info.title: PDF Encryption Types
tools.pdfUnlock.info.text: PDFs support two password types: an Owner password (restricts printing, editing, and copying) and a User password (prevents opening entirely). If you know the password, this tool decrypts the file and saves an unrestricted copy. It cannot crack unknown passwords — it simply removes protection when you provide the correct key.
tools.pgpKeys.meta.title: PGP Key Generator — encrypt.click
tools.pgpKeys.meta.description: Generate OpenPGP-compatible RSA key pairs in your browser. Public and private keys are created client-side and never sent to a server.
tools.pgpKeys.subtitle: Create new OpenPGP key pairs for email encryption and signing. Everything runs locally in your browser; no keys are uploaded.
tools.pgpKeys.info.title: Security Warning
tools.pgpKeys.info.text: PGP private keys are long-lived identifiers. Protect them with a strong passphrase and store only in trusted, encrypted keyrings. Losing control of your private key compromises all messages encrypted to you.
tools.pgpKeys.name: Name
tools.pgpKeys.passphrasePlaceholder: Protects your private key at rest
tools.pgpKeys.failedToGenerate: Failed to generate PGP key pair.
tools.qrGen.meta.title: Secure QR Generator — Tracker-Free Codes
tools.qrGen.meta.description: Generate clean, secure QR codes for URLs and text. Customize colors and resolution without any hidden tracking or data logging.
tools.qrGen.subtitle: QR codes are often used for tracking. Ours are 100% static images generated locally. No mid-redirects. No tracking.
tools.qrGen.info.title: Privacy-First QR Codes
tools.qrGen.info.text: Most online QR generators route your link through a tracking redirect. Our codes point directly to your destination — no analytics middleware, no shortened URLs, no third-party servers. The QR is generated as a static image in your browser using the qrcode library. Error correction level M ensures ~15% of the code can be damaged and still scan.
tools.rsa.meta.title: RSA Key Generator — Asymmetric Cryptography
tools.rsa.meta.description: Generate secure RSA public/private key pairs locally in your browser for asymmetric encryption and digital signatures.
tools.rsa.subtitle: Secure, offline generation of asymmetric key pairs. Your private key never leaves your memory.
tools.rsa.info.title: Security Warning
tools.rsa.info.text: Private keys are extremely sensitive. If someone obtains your private key, they can decrypt any data intended for you or forge your identity. Never store your keys in unencrypted cloud storage.
tools.sshKeys.meta.title: SSH Key Generator — encrypt.click
tools.sshKeys.meta.description: Generate SSH RSA key pairs locally in your browser in OpenSSH format. Private keys never leave your device.
tools.sshKeys.subtitle: Generate OpenSSH-compatible RSA key pairs entirely in your browser. Perfect for Git, servers, and secure shells.
tools.sshKeys.info.title: Security Warning
tools.sshKeys.info.text: Never share your private key. Anyone with this key can log in as you. Store it in a secure, encrypted location and rotate keys periodically.
tools.steganography.meta.title: Steganography — Covert Communication
tools.steganography.meta.description: Hide secret messages inside regular image files. Advanced LSB (Least Significant Bit) encoding combined with AES-256 encryption.
tools.steganography.subtitle: Hide your secrets in plain sight. This tool injects encrypted data into the least significant bits of image pixels. To the naked eye, the image remains unchanged.
tools.steganography.info.title: Technical Overview
tools.steganography.info1.title: 1. Hybrid Security:
tools.steganography.info1.text: Your message is first encrypted using AES-256-GCM. Even if someone detects the hidden bits, they cannot read them without your password.
tools.steganography.info2.title: 2. LSB Encoding:
tools.steganography.info2.text: We use the 3 least significant bits of the RGB channels. This provides high capacity while keeping the visual variance below human perception.
tools.steganography.imageTooLarge: Image too large. Please keep under 10 MB.
tools.steganography.messageTooLong: Message too long for this image.
tools.steganography.pleaseProvide: Please provide an image, a message, and a password.
tools.steganography.pleaseProvideImage: Please provide an image and the password.
tools.steganography.decryptFailed: Failed to decrypt. Wrong password or corrupted bits.
tools.photoCipher.meta.title: Photo Cipher — Compression-Proof Steganography
tools.photoCipher.meta.description: Hide encrypted messages inside photos that survive JPEG compression, Discord, and social media. QIM block-luminance encoding with AES-256 encryption.
tools.photoCipher.subtitle: Hide secrets inside any photo — even after Discord, Instagram, or Twitter re-compress it. Block-luminance encoding burns data into the image structure, not fragile pixel bits.
tools.photoCipher.anyFormat: JPEG, PNG, WebP — any format works
tools.photoCipher.imageTooLarge: Image too large. Please keep under 10 MB.
tools.photoCipher.imageLoadFailed: Could not load image. Try a different file.
tools.photoCipher.messageTooLong: Message too long for this image. Use a higher resolution photo.
tools.photoCipher.messageHidden: Message burned into photo! Download below.
tools.photoCipher.pleaseProvide: Please provide a photo, a message, and a password.
tools.photoCipher.pleaseProvideImage: Please provide a photo and the password.
tools.photoCipher.noHiddenMessage: No hidden message found. Wrong password or no data embedded.
tools.photoCipher.decryptFailed: Failed to recover. Wrong password or too much compression damage.
tools.photoCipher.imageTooSmall: Image too small to contain any hidden data.
tools.photoCipher.info.title: How Photo Cipher Works
tools.photoCipher.info.text: Unlike classic steganography which hides data in the least significant bits (destroyed by JPEG compression), Photo Cipher burns encrypted data into the brightness structure of 8×8 pixel blocks using Quantization Index Modulation (QIM). Each data bit is embedded 7 times across randomly shuffled blocks for error correction. JPEG compression preserves average block brightness, so the message survives even aggressive re-encoding by Discord, Twitter, or Instagram. The block order is determined by your password, so without it, an attacker cannot even tell which blocks carry data.
tools.timeCapsule.meta.title: Time Capsule — Timelock Encryption
tools.timeCapsule.meta.description: Encrypt messages that can only be opened after a chosen future time using drand timelock encryption.
tools.timeCapsule.subtitle: Lock a message to the future. Timelock encryption using public randomness from the drand network – your secrets stay local and only unlock once the network reaches your chosen time.
tools.timeCapsule.footnote: This tool contacts the public drand network to fetch randomness beacons only. Your message and keys never leave your browser.
tools.timeCapsule.messagePlaceholder: Write something your future self (or someone else) can only read later...
tools.timeCapsule.pastePlaceholder: Paste a Time Capsule string here...
tools.timeCapsule.useManualUnix: Use manual Unix timestamp instead of the picker
tools.timeCapsule.errorFuture: Unlock time must be in the future.
tools.timeCapsule.errorAfterGenesis: Unlock time must be after the drand network genesis.
tools.timeCapsule.info.title: How Timelock Encryption Works
tools.timeCapsule.info.text: This tool uses the drand distributed randomness network. Your message is encrypted against a future randomness beacon that doesn't exist yet. The drand network produces a new beacon every 3 seconds — once it reaches your chosen round, the decryption key becomes publicly available. No single party can decrypt early because the randomness is collectively generated by independent nodes worldwide.
tools.timeCapsule.tooEarly: Too early or invalid ciphertext. This message is locked until {time}.
tools.token.meta.title: Secure Token Generator — API Keys & Secrets
tools.token.meta.description: Generate high-entropy cryptographically secure random tokens for API keys, passwords, and secrets.
tools.token.subtitle: Industrial-grade entropy for your infrastructure and application secrets.
tools.token.info.title: Cryptographic Safety
tools.token.info.text: Tokens are derived from the Web Crypto API's cryptographically secure random number generator (CSPRNG). They are suitable for session IDs, CSRF tokens, and permanent API keys.
tools.uuidUlid.meta.title: UUID & ULID Generator — Secure Unique Identifiers
tools.uuidUlid.meta.description: Generate cryptographically secure UUID v4 and lexicographically sortable ULIDs instantly in your browser.
tools.uuidUlid.subtitle: Fast, offline-ready generators for modern distributed systems.
tools.uuidUlid.info1.title: UUID v4
tools.uuidUlid.info1.text: Randomly generated 128-bit identifiers. Statistically unique enough for most global scale applications.
tools.uuidUlid.info2.title: ULID
tools.uuidUlid.info2.text: Sortable identifiers that include a timestamp. Ideal for database primary keys where ordering matters.
tools.vigenere.meta.title: Vigenère Cipher — Polyalphabetic Cryptography
tools.vigenere.meta.description: Master the 'le chiffre indéchiffrable'. The Vigenère cipher uses a keyword to provide complex polyalphabetic encryption.
tools.vigenere.subtitle: Advanced substitution using a series of interwoven Caesar ciphers based on the letters of a keyword.
tools.vigenere.info.title: The Unbreakable Cipher?
tools.vigenere.info.text: For three centuries the Vigenère cipher was considered 'le chiffre indéchiffrable' (the undecipherable cipher). It uses a keyword to shift each letter by a different amount, defeating simple frequency analysis. In 1863 Friedrich Kasiski published a method to break it by finding repeated patterns. Today it serves as an excellent introduction to polyalphabetic substitution.
tools.watermark.meta.title: ID Watermarker — Protecting Your Documents
tools.watermark.meta.description: Add protection overlays to your identity documents. Prevent the unauthorized reuse of your ID cards and passports when verifying identity online.
tools.watermark.subtitle: When sending sensitive documents, always specify the recipient and date. It makes the image useless for identity thieves.
tools.watermark.verificationNote: Verification companies often reject documents without clear intent. Protect your identity.
tools.watermark.info.title: Why Watermark Your IDs?
tools.watermark.info.text: When you send a photo of your ID for online verification, you create a perfect copy that could be reused for identity theft. Adding a visible watermark with the recipient's name and today's date makes the image useless to anyone else. Always specify exactly who it's for and when — it's a simple habit that drastically reduces your risk.
tools.deadDrop.textPlaceholder: Write something to share as a one-shot, URL-only message...
tools.deadDrop.payloadNote: Payload is compressed, encrypted locally with AES‑GCM + PBKDF2, and stored entirely in the URL fragment. Nothing is sent to any server.
tools.deadDrop.privacyNote: Privacy note: The short link is created by {provider}. They see the full URL (including the fragment). Using a shortener reduces link-only privacy.
tools.deadDrop.encryptedPayload: This link contains an encrypted payload. Enter the password to unlock it.
tools.deadDrop.errorNoData: No data found in URL hash.
tools.deadDrop.errorOpen: Could not open this drop. The password may be wrong or the link is corrupted.
tools.deadDrop.errorFileTooLarge: File too large for URL. Please keep under ~10KB.
tools.deadDrop.errorTextTooLarge: Text is too large for a URL. Please shorten it.
tools.deadDrop.errorEnterText: Enter some text or select a file.
tools.hashLab.dropFile: Drop a file here or browse
tools.passwordEntropy.entropyNote: Entropy measures randomness. A password with >80 bits is generally safe against brute-force attacks.
tools.passwordEntropy.entropyPerWord: Each word adds ~14 bits of entropy · Total: {total} bits
